elements.label: sec
elements.text:
A&Q Hydro Power Project – Consultant Tender
Rev.no.: 00
Rev. date: 23.09.2025
Scope of the Project

elements.label: para
elements.text:
Aasiaat and Qasigiannguit are two cities in Greenland located at the southern part of the
Disko Bay area in Greenland. Today light, power and heat are supplied with electricity from
diesel generators and oil-ﬁred boilers.

elements.label: para
elements.text: Energy need for 2019 and expected forecast from 2026-2050 is outlined in table below

elements.label: para
elements.text:
Total energy need for
light/power and heat [MWh]

elements.label: para
elements.text:
As part of an overall strategy outlined in “Sector Plan for Energy and Water Supply 2017” a goal
is to widely implement green energy where possible in 2030. Part of that goal is to displace
fossil fuel from the supply of Qasigiannguit and Aasiaat.

elements.label: para
elements.text:
The Greenlandic parliament, Inatsisartut, have with Act no. 22 of 1. December 2021
established the framework for construction, ﬁnancing and operation of hydropower stations
with necessary facilities to supply of Nuuk and Qasigiannguit and Aasiaat.

elements.label: para
elements.text: For a new hydropower station to supply Qasigiannguit and Aasiaat, the following is proposed

elements.label: para
elements.text:
The hydroelectric power plant utilizes the water resources from the Kuussuup Tasia
catchment area and supplies Aasiaat and Qasigiannguit with energy for electricity and
heating.

elements.label: para
elements.text:
The facility uses Qinngap Ilulialeeraa (Lake 3) as the upper reservoir and Kuussuup Tasia (Lake
2) as the lower reservoir and intake basin. A regulated transfer tunnel will be constructed
between the two lakes. No dam will be built.

elements.label: para
elements.text:
The inlet tunnel leads to an underground power station located near the fjord to the north. The
water is discharged into the fjord through a short tunnel. The power plant also includes an
above-ground portal building, from which the access tunnel leads to the power station.

elements.label: para
elements.text:
The power station is expected to be equipped with three Francis turbines; each rated at 7.0
MW. All structures must be designed and dimensioned with consideration for the presence of
continuous permafrost in the area.

elements.label: para
elements.text:
From the power station, one transmission line will run to a transformer station in
Qasigiannguit and another line to a transformer station in Aasiaat. When constructing the

elements.label: para
elements.text:
transmission line to Aasiaat, special consideration must be given to crossing the Ramsar site
Naternaq (the Clay Plain).

elements.label: para
elements.text:
The hydropower plant’s potential from 2026–2050 can cover the future electricity demand and
between 92.5–94.7% of interruptible heating needs, assuming a heat demand of 18 MWh/year
per inhabitant, with production at the town gate averaging approximately 84 GWh/year over
the period. Interruptible electric heating will be fully covered if the heat demand remains
below 15.5 MWh/year per inhabitant. When the heat demand exceeds this level, oil heating
will be required.

elements.label: sub_sec
elements.text: 3 Prerequisites for the Construction of the Facility

elements.label: para
elements.text:
The hydroelectric facility is located approximately 20 km east-southeast of Qasigiannguit. The
facility utilizes water from the Kuussuaq River, which is intercepted at the outlet of Kuussuup
Tasia. Lakes Kuussuup Tasia and Qinngap Ilulialeeraa are used as reservoirs for the facility.

elements.label: para
elements.text:
These lakes are hereafter referred to as “Lake 2” and “Lake 3.” “Lake 1” refers to the lake
immediately downstream of Lake 2, but it is not included in this construction of the
hydropower plant. The hydropower plant is situated at the Kangersuneq fjord.

elements.label: para
elements.text:
The hydropower facility utilizes the catchment area around Lake 2 and Lake 3. In addition to
precipitation, Lake 3 also receives runoƯ from a glacier, and its outﬂow goes to Lake 2.

elements.label: para
elements.text:
Both lakes are used as reservoirs (see Appendix 3). Lake 3 is the main reservoir, with storage
capacity created by lowering the lake level by 32 m from its natural surface elevation at +182
m. The reservoir is drawn down in proportion to consumption and supplies Lake 2 through a
transfer tunnel with a controllable valve.

elements.label: para
elements.text:
The secondary reservoir is created in Lake 2 by lowering the lake level by 8 m from its natural
surface elevation at +143 m. From the intake at Lake 2, water is conveyed through a tunnel to
the underground power station near the fjord.
